articles.headline: A Tablet to Rival the Leader
articles.snippet: Google’s Nexus 7, a sleek, full-blown tablet with the latest version of Android 4.1, is playing Follow the Leader with Apple’s iPad, David Pogue says.
articles.abstract: Google’s Nexus 7, a sleek, full-blown tablet with the latest version of Android 4.1, is playing Follow the Leader with Apple’s iPad, David Pogue says.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can love Apple or you can hate Apple, but one thing’s for sure: its favorite game is Lead the Industry. And the industry’s favorite game is Follow the Leader.

articles.headline: Spain’s Banking Crisis Moves Into the Courtroom
articles.snippet: A raft of lawsuits by politicians, shareholders and prosecutors against several large banks could complicate efforts to by Spain to clean up its banking sector.
articles.abstract: A raft of lawsuits by politicians, shareholders and prosecutors against several large banks could complicate efforts to by Spain to clean up its banking sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s banking crisis has moved into the courtroom.

articles.headline: Luring Online Shoppers Offline
articles.snippet: Some big retailers are transforming their stores into extensions of their online operations, adding return centers, pickup locations and free shipping outlets.
articles.abstract: Some big retailers are transforming their stores into extensions of their online operations, adding return centers, pickup locations and free shipping outlets.
articles.lead_paragraph: As online shopping has surged, traditional retailers have lost millions in sales to so-called showrooming — when shoppers check out products in stores that they then buy from Web sites like Amazon. It has gotten so bad that Best Buy even replaces standard bar codes with special Best Buy-only codes on big ticket items so they cannot be scanned and compared online.

articles.headline: Romney Now Says Health Mandate by Obama Is a Tax
articles.snippet: Days after his spokesman said the requirement that people have insurance was not a tax, Mitt Romney said it was, aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party.
articles.abstract: Days after his spokesman said the requirement that people have insurance was not a tax, Mitt Romney said it was, aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFEBORO, N.H. — Mitt Romney declared on Wednesday that President Obama’s health care mandate was in fact a tax, shifting his campaign’s characterization of the law and aligning himself with the conservative voices in his party.

articles.headline: Car-Pooling Makes a Surge on Apps and Social Media
articles.snippet: Helped by advances in technology and social networking, sharing rides is becoming easier and more popular in the United States.
articles.abstract: Helped by advances in technology and social networking, sharing rides is becoming easier and more popular in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The annual ritual of piling into the car for the great American summer road trip has a new twist as more travelers are inviting strangers along for part of the ride.

articles.headline: Oil Backed Up, Iranians Put It on Idled Ships
articles.snippet: As its oil inventory grows because of tough sanctions, Iran has taken to repainting and renaming its tankers, concealing their origins in a bid to find buyers.
articles.abstract: As its oil inventory grows because of tough sanctions, Iran has taken to repainting and renaming its tankers, concealing their origins in a bid to find buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANDAR ABBAS, Iran — The hulking tanker Neptune was floating aimlessly this week in the warm waters of the Persian Gulf, a fresh coat of black paint barely concealing its true identity as an Iranian ship loaded with hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil that no one is willing to buy.
articles.byline: By Thomas Erdbrink and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Three Central Banks Act to Stimulate More Borrowing
articles.snippet: Banks in Europe and China announced measures to address concern about waning economic growth, a response that was all the more striking because it was uncoordinated.
articles.abstract: Banks in Europe and China announced measures to address concern about waning economic growth, a response that was all the more striking because it was uncoordinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Concerned about waning economic growth, central banks in Europe and China announced measures Thursday to increase borrowing and spending by businesses and consumers, a response that was all the more striking because it was uncoordinated.
